content: @WG-prioritization :wave:, please add a :wave: so we all can see who is participating in the meeting :)
as a way to kick off this meeting, let's recap a bit what's our current status
typically we have been prioritizing issues async but we have also been doing a full hour sync meeting to finish the rest of the stuff we need in order to complete the agenda
we've also proposed to start doing everything async and this week we won't have a sync meeting
the idea is that tomorrow, during all day, we will be doing all the work we use to do but asyncronously
and meanwhile we have been trying to automate more stuff in order to run our process fully async

Let's define a day then? :p
More seriously though, how would we handle timezones?
ahh I thought we have defined a day already :)
sorry about that
the idea would be to do that tomorrow
so every wednesday
Maybe I just missed the conversation :slight_smile:
what I can do is add a compiler team event for the whole day about this
and about timezones I'm not sure if that's a problem, most of the stuff can be started whenever someone wants to start it
the important thing is to have a complete agenda for thursday morning, at the compiler weekly meeting time
anyway, going to create a calendar event
what I wanted to talk about is https://hackmd.io/P3yvagSSS7yAI2QxhLfPtQ#Tasks
I've came up with that list of tasks, that would be nice to have in order to have our async process working as best as possible

Create a topic per stable/beta nominations, i-nominated and prs-waiting-on-team

We can probably reuse code from I-prioritize? Should I work on an implementation?
yes, there are a lot of things that are kind of ... let's reuse what we have
if you want to work on that is great
I think one of the things we could do today is split some work between us if people are willing to take some tasks
I can totally pair in some task with somebody that needs help or whatever :)
or I can just do some of the tasks by myself :)
but these 2 ...

About that, I was wondering if having like a meta-topic here on Zulip that lists every conversation about e.g. I-nominated or P-critical so that making the meeting should be easier, I am a bit worried that topics might get a bit lost.

- Create a topic per stable/beta nominations, i-nominated and prs-waiting-on-team
- Create a topic per P-critical and P-high regressions
I think are the two most important to have our async process flow in a nice way
:+1:

LeSeulArtichaut said:

About that, I was wondering if having like a meta-topic here on Zulip that lists every conversation about e.g. I-nominated or P-critical so that making the meeting should be easier, I am a bit worried that topics might get a bit lost.

unsure if I understand what you meant
you want a new topic with a list of all I-prioritize?
I would propose to have a topic where Triagebot could put all of the issues that we'd need to add to the agenda
well I don't think that's needed
what is placed in the agenda is what our script currently outputs
or did you meant, the issues we still need to prioritize?

Santiago Pastorino said:

or did you meant, the issues we still need to prioritize?

Could be interesting too, I feel like some issues get lost in the pile of to-prioritize issues
there are no lost issues :)
I meant, I end reviewing all of them and leaving the list empty before the meeting
what I usually do is ... usually on wednesday I scroll to the meeting topic and start going up from there, issue after issue and check what the status is

Is there a way to search a topic in a given stream? Sometimes I want to access the discussion prioritization about a specific issue and the only way I can find the conversation is to manually look at the name of the topics
I usually figure that some have been already closed, others have been prioritized, if so, I check the priority anyway otherwise I bump them up and try to prioritize
That's a bit off-topic, I'm sorry, I wouldn't want to hold the meeting for details like this :confused:
at the end of that process I go to the list of issues with I-prioritize to see if there's still some of them, if so, I search that topic on zulip and prioritize
and at that point we clear the list
(deleted)

LeSeulArtichaut said:

Is there a way to search a topic in a given stream? Sometimes I want to access the discussion prioritization about a specific issue and the only way I can find the conversation is to manually look at the name of the topics

so ... I just click more topics and use browser search
but you can also try to send a message to this stream and on the topic write something about the issue, the correct topic will show up
@LeSeulArtichaut you can search for the issue number in the search bar above
since it is part of the title name, you'll get a hit :D
yeah, or what @DPC is saying
so going back a bit to the tasks idea, do someone have time and want to jump into some of those?
https://hackmd.io/P3yvagSSS7yAI2QxhLfPtQ#Tasks

DPC said:

LeSeulArtichaut you can search for the issue number in the search bar above

Oh, awesome, I was searching on the navebar to the left and finding nothing :big_smile:
that's a stream search :)

Santiago Pastorino said:

so going back a bit to the tasks idea, do someone have time and want to jump into some of those?

I guess I'm going to assume silence as I'd really love to do some of those but I have zero time :) :heart:

Santiago Pastorino said:

so going back a bit to the tasks idea, do someone have time and want to jump into some of those?

I'd like to have a look at the list and maybe try to get one through (possibly with some guidance because I'm lacking context)
(hello everyone, btw)
@apiraino :+1:, I'd be willing to pair if you want and guide you through
@LeSeulArtichaut you were mentioning that you're going to take one of those similars to the code we already have in I-prioritize?
if so, which one? so I can tackle the other one if that makes sense
I assigned myself to the 2 points you mentionned above
Well I think I can do both at the same time
They are so similar to each other
cool
yeah they are so similar :)
I'd like to use the opportunity also to discuss some stuff about the rest of the tasks
for instance
Automatically beta/stable nominate a P-critical issue once it’s fixed. Maybe P-high too?.
I cannot edit the markdown (w/o signup) but I'd say @Santiago Pastorino we can have a look together at the "Make script output a bit better" section, wdy?

Santiago Pastorino said:

Automatically beta/stable nominate a P-critical issue once it’s fixed. Maybe P-high too?.

I'm not sure what would be the right way to do so, cc @simulacrum

apiraino said:

I cannot edit the markdown (w/o signup) but I'd say Santiago Pastorino we can have a look together at the "Make script output a bit better" section, wdy?

yes :+1:
Yeah not sure either
can we fire something when an issue is closed and look for a label?
unsure if that would be triagebot job
Seems feasible
But it has some caveats, e.g. issues that needs-test?
yeah, seemed feasible to me too

LeSeulArtichaut said:

But it has some caveats, e.g. issues that needs-test?

but at the same time that's always reviewed by a human at some point
once we figure something is beta-nominated we can check and in case the label is wrong, remove it and adjust the script if possible
just in case, my intention is to not miss backports of some important issues but beta/stable nominating those doesn't mean we need to hold that nomination
maybe is better if we just open a zulip topic requesting for nomination
well, I think I prefer this, so a topic can be created in the wg-prioritization stream and we can see if the issue deserves a backport or not
and then nominate
but we can do that if triagebot receives an event when an issue is closed, otherwise not possible
cc @LeSeulArtichaut
We can also always keep an eye on the progress of critical issues manually if automation is too difficult
if there are always less than 5 critical issues that should be manageable
yeah, but I'd also check P-high ones :)
worth adding that, beta nominations are tracked during release meetings
of course not all deserves backports but some for sure

DPC said:

worth adding that, beta nominations are tracked during release meetings

:+1:, but did you meant something specific about this automation?
no just in general, so that we are aware that we don't miss any nominated issues
yeah, so about nominations the process work in 3 steps
1. someone nominates for a backport
1. compiler team accepts/rejects the backport

Another approach is to ask reviewers to nominate when the bug is high priority. I'm not sure this add a lot of work for them, since I'd expect that they look at the issues before reviewing, but I'm probably wrong
1. release team makes the backport happen
i'm okay with P-critical, but P-high might be too much to be considered for backporting

I'm talking about 1, in this case I'd say that we can consider more issues for nomination by checking P-critical and P-high issues and consider those for nomination. Anyway, t-compiler will have the last say, they can totally reject the backport

DPC said:

i'm okay with P-critical, but P-high might be too much to be considered for backporting

how many P-high issues are fixed per week?
i wish i had numbers on that :D
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?q=is%3Aclosed+label%3AP-high
we had 6 on may
it's not really a lot I think
Maybe include critical bugs too?
yes, I was just looking for p-high but yeah with p-critical is neither a lot
So we can have an idea of the number of backports per week
maybe we can answer the main question in better way - if we look at existing P-high issues, how many of those would be worthy to be nominated for a backport?

Santiago Pastorino said:

yes, I was just looking for p-high but yeah with p-critical is neither a lot

Sure, hopefully :D
there are 3 p-critical on may
so a total of 9
Way less than 3 per week on average
I think it's manageable
then fine :slight_smile:

DPC said:

maybe we can answer the main question in better way - if we look at existing P-high issues, how many of those would be worthy to be nominated for a backport?

I guess it depends on how bad the issue is and how complex the solution for this is among other things
maybe instead of how complex also how risky it is to apply the backport to stable/beta without going through nightlies
should we consider backport as a factor during prioritisation?
do you meant if we should do this work?
if so it's a good question :)
but I'm not sure what you're saying exactly :)
as in, if we feel something might get backported, we can give it a higher prioritisation
ahh ok, another good question then :)
but I wouldn't do that
because in order to know if we would backport you would need to solve the problem first
uhmm true
and if you have the solution ready in your head you better write a PR :)
We can still evaluate the benefit of backporting, even though we don't know the risk yet?
yes
I meant, I know what you're trying to say, the thing is in my opinion thinking that way doesn't add anything new
so ... you would backport something because it's a bad bug that impacts a lot of users
and you don't need to evaluate the benefit of the backport to then prioritize in this kind of cases
you just go and prioritize it as a severe bug
and then considering that it's a severe bug and a solution to that bug you see if a backport may be a good idea
at least that's what you'd do in my opinion
I have a good example also ... :)
#71896
yeah again which is why i was suggesting only p-critical, because there's rarely an intersection between P-critical issues and ones that need to be backported
if you look at this PR, it fixes 2 P-critical issues and it's just less than 2 lines of code
one would quickly jump into the conclusion of ... let's backport that one

Santiago Pastorino said:

#71896

sorry fixed the PR, I was referring to this one #71896
so one would quickly say let's backport but ...
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/71896#issuecomment-626662024
was wondering how the first one you linked is considered 2 lines :D
it affects some crates and it's risky because it changes semantics
anyway, we are 50 minutes in
we have 10 more minutes

digressing a bit, going back to the hackmd, is this:

Add I-prioritize to I-unsound :boom: issues that are not requires-nightly

something you want to do right now, or somehing you wish to be automated?
Automated I think
I'd say both
i can do the first part right now
I meant, if you see some I-sound issues just manually I-prioritize them
i can get the triage members, who add `I-sound to add that as well
the problem with manual intervention is that we can do now but if we forget we may skip next week's ones

DPC said:

i can get the triage members, who add I-unsound to add that as well

yeah but if we automate it won't be needed
and extra overhead for them
And we have the needed infrastructure for it
We'd just need to modify triagebot.toml I guess

Propose a strategy to review all P-high issues

We could probably spend the last minutes on this?
:+1: to both things :slight_smile:
@LeSeulArtichaut thoughts?
Okay i have someone working on adding the I-prioritize to the unsound issues
As pnkfelix proposed, we could triage a portion of the P-high issues per week
define triage :)
Maybe like 1/4 of the issues, so that we triage all of them in a month
do you mean check the progress?
Yes, I think that would be enough
if we are going that route, I'd prefer doing it batching by release instead of month
Sorry I'm filing the PR for triagebot in parallel :big_smile:
so I think triaging is ...

• Check progress
  • Notify appropriate people and/or ICE-breakers.
  • Nominate the ones worth discussing.
  • Assign if possible
something along those lines I guess

DPC said:

if we are going that route, I'd prefer doing it batching by release instead of month

so you meant instead of 1/4, doing 1/6 of them?
yep
mainly, ensuring we track all of them before a release happens
@DPC unsure how many I-unsound we have but ...
this is about P-high :P
Quite a few, appearently :D
hehe wg-triage people are trying to kill us
That's rivalry
I'd say let's do this by batches
Yeah i have requested the person to do the remaining next week :D
hehehe, I already regret about my idea :joy: of prioritizing I-sound issues

DPC said:

Yeah i have requested the person to do the remaining next week :D

LOL, there are 21 24 issues to prioritize + the rest of the stuff we originally had
I'd say please revert this
okay
@LeSeulArtichaut do you think we should prioritize them now?
we can leave the threads open and prioritize them during the week or whenever :D
hmmm, ok if you guys want to do that, I'm not going to oppose :)
I think it might be fine to keep them prioritized and slowly work through them during the next few weeks :thinking:
As long as we don't miss actually new regressions because of this
no we'll prioritise newly marked ones over these

lcnr said:

As long as we don't miss actually new regressions because of this

this is my fear and this is why we are taking 4 stable-to-stable-regressions per week
anyway, time is up, it was a pleasure everyone :wave:
so the next meeting is in 2 weeks?
yes
Some of them already have prioritization labels though
I'll remove prioritization for these? @DPC what do you think?
I-prioritize should be added if T-compiler or libs-impl label exist and if not requires-nightly and not P-low, P-medium, P-high or P-critical
Opened #73181 too
ah ok
i forgot to pass on the requires-nightly part :D
No worries, I'll remove the labels when needed
Sorry for the chaos!
That happens sometimes :slight_smile:

Elinvynia said:

Sorry for the chaos!

no worries, thanks for helping :heart:
I'm unsure about #63818, it seems like a compiler bug but it's tagged as T-lang
Alright I'm done :slight_smile:
in general we should prioritize T-compiler and libs-impl issues, I didn't read that particular issue yet but it may have been nominated for T-lang discussion maybe? cc @simulacrum
I expect this to be in t-langish camp within purview of UCG
:+1:
removed I-prioritize from it
@Santiago Pastorino I opened triagebot#615 for the "open topics for XXX" stuff
cc @simulacrum please tell me if the configuration format seems good to you so that I can start working on it
@LeSeulArtichaut I've thought more or less about the same idea :)
That means it's a good idea, right? :D
no, that we both had a terribly bad idea :joy:
kidding, kidding, looks good
simulacrum approved too, so I'll work on it as soon as I'm done with bisection the other issue
:+1:
Assuming I have the time :fingers_crossed:
@Santiago Pastorino Opened triagebot#616, going to bed now :in_bed:
@LeSeulArtichaut At a first glance it looks good. Tomorrow I'm going to try to make a proper review :).
@Santiago Pastorino I opened #73247 to configure Triagebot for the new Zulip notifications :slight_smile:
@LeSeulArtichaut should we r+ and as soon as it is merged, merge the other one?
I believe we should do that, yes
Or rather merge the triagebot one first if possible
Because merging the rust one will cause config parsing errors
Whereas merging the triagebot one will only make it so automation won’t work until the rust PR is merged
yeah but ... merging into rust takes more time
also I wonder if we should tweak a bit the messages
like ...
https://hackmd.io/WJ0G17DHTHGgv0OW9I2PxA?view
so once the topic is opened, we leave some brief explanation about what to do
